questions.question_text: Give an example of a metal which (i) is a liquid at room temperature. (ii) can be easily cut with a knife. (iii) is the best conductor of heat. (iv) is a poor conductor of heat.
hints: Recall physical properties of metals discussed in section 3.1.1.
Think about metals like mercury, sodium, silver, and lead.

questions.question_text: Explain the meanings of malleable and ductile.
hints: Refer to Activities 3.3 and 3.4.
Define based on ability to be hammered into sheets or drawn into wires.

questions.question_text: Why is sodium kept immersed in kerosene oil?
hints: Consider reactivity of sodium with oxygen and water.
Recall safety precautions mentioned in Activity 3.2 and Do You Know section.

questions.question_text: Write equations for the reactions of (i) iron with steam (ii) calcium and potassium with water.
hints: Refer to section 3.2.2 for reactions with water/steam.
Balance the chemical equations.

questions.question_text:
Samples of four metals A, B, C and D were taken and added to the following solution one by one. The results obtained have been tabulated as follows.

Metal | Iron(II) sulphate | Zinc sulphate | Copper(II) sulphate | Silver nitrate
A | No reaction | Displacement | - | -
B | Displacement | - | No reaction | No reaction
C | No reaction | No reaction | No reaction | Displacement
D | No reaction | No reaction | No reaction | No reaction

Use the Table above to answer the following questions about metals A, B, C and D.
(i) Which is the most reactive metal?
(ii) What would you observe if B is added to a solution of Copper(II) sulphate?
(iii) Arrange the metals A, B, C and D in the order of decreasing reactivity.
hints: Use displacement reaction principles from section 3.2.4.
Compare reactivity based on which metal displaces another from its salt solution.

questions.question_text: Which gas is produced when dilute hydrochloric acid is added to a reactive metal? Write the chemical reaction when iron reacts with dilute H2SO4.
hints: Recall reaction of metals with acids from section 3.2.3.
Hydrogen gas is evolved; write balanced equation for Fe + H2SO4.

questions.question_text: What would you observe when zinc is added to a solution of iron(II) sulphate? Write the chemical reaction that takes place.
hints: Check reactivity series: zinc is above iron.
Displacement reaction will occur; zinc displaces iron.

questions.question_text:
(i) Write the electron-dot structures for sodium, oxygen and magnesium.
(ii) Show the formation of Na2O and MgO by the transfer of electrons.
(iii) What are the ions present in these compounds?
hints: Refer to section 3.3 for ionic bond formation.
Draw Lewis structures; show electron transfer to form cations and anions.

questions.question_text: Why do ionic compounds have high melting points?
hints: Consider strong electrostatic forces between ions.
Refer to properties in section 3.3.1.

questions.question_text:
Define the following terms.
(i) Mineral
(ii) Ore
(iii) Gangue
hints: Refer to section 3.4 (Occurrence of Metals).
Distinguish between naturally occurring compounds and economically extractable ones.

questions.question_text: Name two metals which are found in nature in the free state.
hints: Recall metals low in reactivity series (section 3.4.1).
Gold, silver, platinum, copper are examples.

questions.question_text: What chemical process is used for obtaining a metal from its oxide?
hints: Refer to reduction processes in sections 3.4.3 to 3.4.5.
Mention reduction using carbon or electrolytic reduction based on reactivity.

questions.question_text:
Metallic oxides of zinc, magnesium and copper were heated with the following metals.

Metal | Zinc | Magnesium | Copper
Zinc oxide | - | - | -
Magnesium oxide | - | - | -
Copper oxide | - | - | -

In which cases will you find displacement reactions taking place?
hints: Use reactivity series (Table 3.2).
A more reactive metal can displace a less reactive metal from its oxide.

questions.question_text: Which metals do not corrode easily?
hints: Consider noble metals and corrosion-resistant alloys.
Refer to sections 3.5 and 3.5.1.

questions.question_text: What are alloys?
hints: Define as homogeneous mixtures of metals or metals with non-metals.
Refer to section 3.5.1 for examples and properties.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following pairs will give displacement reactions?
(a) NaCl solution and copper metal
(b) MgCl2 solution and aluminium metal
(c) FeSO4 solution and silver metal
(d) AgNO3 solution and copper metal.
hints: Check reactivity series: a more reactive metal displaces a less reactive one from its salt solution.
Copper is less reactive than silver but more than silver? Verify positions.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following methods is suitable for preventing an iron frying pan from rusting?
(a) Applying grease
(b) Applying paint
(c) Applying a coating of zinc
(d) All of the above.
hints: Recall corrosion prevention methods from section 3.5.1.
All methods create a barrier to moisture and air.

questions.question_text:
An element reacts with oxygen to give a compound with a high melting point. This compound is also soluble in water. The element is likely to be
(a) calcium
(b) carbon
(c) silicon
(d) iron.
hints: Consider metal oxides vs. non-metal oxides.
Metal oxides are basic and often soluble, forming alkalis.

questions.question_text:
Food cans are coated with tin and not with zinc because
(a) zinc is costlier than tin.
(b) zinc has a higher melting point than tin.
(c) zinc is more reactive than tin.
(d) zinc is less reactive than tin.
hints: Think about reactivity and food safety.
More reactive metals may react with acidic food contents.

questions.question_text:
You are given a hammer, a battery, a bulb, wires and a switch.
(a) How could you use them to distinguish between samples of metals and non-metals?
(b) Assess the usefulness of these tests in distinguishing between metals and non-metals.
hints: Use physical properties (malleability, sonority) and electrical conductivity.
Set up a circuit to test conductivity; hammer to test malleability/sonority.

questions.question_text: What are amphoteric oxides? Give two examples of amphoteric oxides.
hints: Define oxides that react with both acids and bases.
Refer to section 3.2.1 for examples like Al2O3 and ZnO.

questions.question_text: Name two metals which will displace hydrogen from dilute acids, and two metals which will not.
hints: Refer to activity series: metals above H displace H2; those below do not.
Examples: Zn, Mg displace; Cu, Ag do not.

questions.question_text: In the electrolytic refining of a metal M, what would you take as the anode, the cathode and the electrolyte?
hints: Recall electrolytic refining process from section 3.4.6.
Anode: impure M; Cathode: pure M; Electrolyte: salt solution of M.

questions.question_text:
Pratyush took sulphur powder on a spatula and heated it. He collected the gas evolved by inverting a test tube over it, as shown in figure below.
(a) What will be the action of gas on
(i) dry litmus paper?
(ii) moist litmus paper?
(b) Write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction taking place.
hints: Sulphur burning produces SO2, an acidic oxide.
Acidic oxides turn moist blue litmus red; no effect on dry litmus.

questions.question_text: State two ways to prevent the rusting of iron.
hints: Recall methods from section 3.5.1: painting, galvanizing, alloying, etc.

questions.question_text: What type of oxides are formed when non-metals combine with oxygen?
hints: Non-metal oxides are acidic or neutral.
Examples: CO2, SO2, P2O5 are acidic.

questions.question_text:
Give reasons
(a) Platinum, gold and silver are used to make jewellery.
(b) Sodium, potassium and lithium are stored under oil.
(c) Aluminium is a highly reactive metal, yet it is used to make utensils for cooking.
(d) Carbonate and sulphide ores are usually converted into oxides during the process of extraction.
hints:
(a) Lustre, malleability, corrosion resistance.
(b) High reactivity with air and water.
(c) Forms protective oxide layer.
(d) Oxides are easier to reduce than sulphides/carbonates.

questions.question_text: You must have seen tarnished copper vessels being cleaned with lemon or tamarind juice. Explain why these sour substances are effective in cleaning the vessels.
hints: Tarnish is basic copper carbonate; acids in lemon/tamarind react with it.
Acid + base â†’ salt + water; removes tarnish layer.

questions.question_text: Differentiate between metal and non-metal on the basis of their chemical properties.
hints: Compare formation of ions, reaction with acids/water, nature of oxides.
Refer to summary points in 'What you have learnt' section.

questions.question_text: A man went door to door posing as a goldsmith. He promised to bring back the glitter of old and dull gold ornaments. An unsuspecting lady gave a set of gold bangles to him which he dipped in a particular solution. The bangles sparkled like new but their weight was reduced drastically. The lady was upset but after a futile argument the man beat a hasty retreat. Can you play the detective to find out the nature of the solution he had used?
hints: Consider aqua regia (HCl + HNO3) that dissolves gold.
Weight loss indicates gold dissolved; surface cleaned but material lost.

questions.question_text: Give reasons why copper is used to make hot water tanks and not steel (an alloy of iron).
hints: Copper is less reactive, does not corrode easily with hot water.
Iron/steel rusts in presence of water and oxygen.
